skill.name: plotly
skill.description: Interactive visualization library. Use when you need hover info, zoom, pan, or web-embeddable charts. Best for dashboards, exploratory analysis, and presentations. For static publication figures use matplotlib or scientific-visualization.
skill.summary: Python graphing library for creating interactive, publication-quality visualizations with 40+ chart types.
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate documentation skill for the Plotly visualization library. All 342 static findings are false positives from the pattern scanner detecting markdown code block delimiters as shell commands, documentation text as malicious keywords, and legitimate API references as threats. No actual security risks present.

content.value_statement: Data visualization often requires complex code and lacks interactivity for exploration. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for creating interactive, publication-quality charts with Plotly, featuring hover tooltips, zoom, pan, and 40+ chart types for dashboards and data analysis.
actual_capabilities: Generate code for 40+ chart types including scatter, line, bar, histogram, heatmap, 3D plots, and geographic maps
Create interactive visualizations with hover tooltips, zoom, pan, and click events for data exploration
Customize chart layouts, colors, themes, and styling for professional presentations and publications
Export charts to HTML, PNG, PDF, and SVG formats for web embedding and static reports
Build complex multi-trace figures and subplots for comparative analysis
Integrate Plotly with pandas DataFrames for seamless data pipeline visualization
limitations: Requires Plotly library installation which may not be available in all environments
Interactive features only work in environments that support HTML rendering or Jupyter notebooks
Large datasets may require performance optimization or data aggregation before visualization
Static export formats require additional dependencies like kaleido or orca

use_cases.title: Dashboard Development
use_cases.description: Build interactive dashboards for business intelligence with real-time data exploration capabilities including filtering, zooming, and hover details.
use_cases.target_user: Data analysts and business intelligence developers

use_cases.title: Scientific Data Visualization
use_cases.description: Create publication-quality charts for research papers, presentations, and reports with precise control over styling and layout.

use_cases.title: Exploratory Data Analysis
use_cases.description: Quickly visualize data distributions, correlations, and patterns with interactive charts for hypothesis generation and data quality assessment.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Chart Creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a scatter plot showing the relationship between temperature and sales using Plotly Express

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Series Line Chart
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate an interactive line chart comparing monthly revenue across three product categories with hover tooltips
prompt_templates.scenario: Time series comparison for business reporting

prompt_templates.title: Custom Styled Visualization
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a histogram with custom colors, bin sizes, and annotations showing data distribution with mean and median lines

prompt_templates.title: Advanced Multi-Plot Layout
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a dashboard with subplots containing a scatter plot, bar chart, and heatmap arranged in a grid layout with shared color scales

output_examples.input: Create a simple scatter plot of x and y data
output_examples.output: Code snippet showing px.scatter() with basic parameters, fig.show() for display, and explanation of interactive features like zoom and hover

output_examples.input: How do I export my Plotly chart to HTML?
output_examples.output: Code example using fig.write_html() with explanation of file path parameter and embedded vs CDN options for JavaScript libraries
Code using go.Surface() with mesh grid data, camera angle configuration, and color scale customization instructions

best_practices: Use Plotly Express for quick standard visualizations and Graph Objects for fine-grained control over complex custom charts
Enable responsive sizing with fig.update_layout for charts that adapt to different screen sizes and container dimensions
Optimize large datasets by aggregating data or using sampling techniques before visualization to maintain interactivity performance
anti_patterns: Avoid using Graph Objects for simple charts when Plotly Express can achieve the same result with less code
Do not create overly complex charts with too many traces or data points that make interaction slow or confusing
Never hardcode chart dimensions without considering responsive design for different display environments

faq.question: When should I use Plotly Express versus Graph Objects?
faq.answer: Use Plotly Express for quick standard visualizations with pandas DataFrames. Use Graph Objects when you need precise control over individual components or chart types not available in Plotly Express.

faq.question: How do I make my charts work in Jupyter notebooks?
faq.answer: Plotly charts display automatically in Jupyter notebooks when you call fig.show(). Ensure you have the notebook renderer installed with pip install notebook.

faq.question: Can I export Plotly charts to static images?
faq.answer: Yes, install kaleido with pip install kaleido, then use fig.write_image for PNG, PDF, or SVG export. HTML export works without additional dependencies.

faq.question: How do I customize chart colors and themes?
faq.answer: Use the color parameter in Plotly Express or update_traces for individual series. Apply built-in themes with fig.update_layout or create custom color scales.

faq.question: What is the difference between show and write methods?
faq.answer: The show method displays charts interactively in supported environments. Write methods like write_html and write_image save charts to files for sharing or embedding.

faq.question: Does this skill require internet connection?
faq.answer: No, Plotly works offline. Charts can be exported with embedded JavaScript libraries for offline viewing without external CDN dependencies.
